author: bananaworld
title: A Wonderful Tribute to All Things Space
review:
...but a fitting tribute to 10266...?

Full disclosure: I love everything that appears on this patch, but will try to remain neutral.

This patch was produced to coïncide with the release of 10266: NASA Apollo 11 Lunar Lander and was sent along free with purchases of that set. Not mentioned at the time was that it was also free for seemingly any purchase over £85; this fact was accidentally discovered when I made another purchase a few days later of some of the (bias warning!) beautiful City Space sets in order to obtain 40335: Space Rocket Ride.

From the long-winded explanation above, you may discern a predisposition towards all things Space-related. Again: I will strive for neutrality.

The Lunar Module

The title on the patch is 'APOLLO LUNAR LANDER' and, indeed, featured front-and-centre is an Apollo Lunar Module (LM). Curiously, it isn't the LM in 10266 but instead the LM from 21309: NASA Apollo Saturn V. Now, that LM is a true triumph of microscale building, but if this a free gift with one set, why feature a picture of a different set...?

The Lunar Surface

A curved, grey, LEGO-studded surface: this is very nicely done. My heart would love to see some craters featured, but my head knows it would be tricky to pull off at this scale of stitching with the limited patch-space available.

... but I'm willing to bet classic craters were included in some of the concept art for this patch!

The Background

Again from 21309, we see an orbiting Command Module (CSM); LEGO can have a pass this time at the inclusion of a component from another set, being as how 10266 doesn't include a CSM. Is that a hint to TLG to produce a minifig-scale CSM? Yes; yes it is.

And so to the elephant in the room: the Classic Space Logo. What on Earth (ha) is that doing there? Obviously, I adore this logo, and it gives me a warm, fuzzy, childhood-nostalgia feeling inside, but it doesn't seem to pertain to the subject matter here. On the other hand, the Classic Space Logo was clearly inspired by the NASA Seal so perhaps its inclusion does indeed relate...

Either way, they get another pass, because, you know, spacelogo, Spacelogo, SPACELOGO!

In Conclusion

The inevitable outcome of this review is that I find this patch fantastic. Yes, it only tangentially relates to the actual set it was released to commemorate, but it is appropriate enough to display alongside it, especially if 21309 is nearby.

Taken as a standalone patch, everything featured on it is wonderful and adds up to a beautiful memento of LEGO's Space themes.
